front.title: Use of Streams in BGP over QUIC

abstract.t: This document specifies the use of QUIC Streams to support multiple BGP sessions over one connection in order to achieve high ressiliency.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) uses TCP as its transport protocol. BGP establishes peer relationship between routers using a TCP session on port 179. TCP provides reliable packet communication.

Multiprotocol Extensions for BGP-4 (MP-BGP) allows BGP to carry information for multiple address families and sub-families. However, only a single TCP connection can reach the Established state with each peer .

As pointed out by , there are some disadvantages of using a single BGP session:
A common criticism of BGP is the fact that most malformed messages cause the session to be terminated. While this behavior is necessary for protocol correctness, one may observe that the protocol machinery of a given implementation may only be defective with respect to a given AFI/SAFI. Thus, it would be desirable to allow the session related to that family to be terminated while leaving other AFI/SAFI unaffected. As BGP is commonly deployed, this is not possible.
A second criticism of BGP is that it is difficult or in some cases impossible to manage control plane resource contention when BGP is used to support diverse services over a single session. In contrast, if a single BGP session carries only information for a single service (or related set of services) it may be easier to manage such contention.

QUIC is a new UDP-based multiplexed and secure transport protocol. QUIC can provide low latency and encrypted transport with resilient connections. specifies the procedure to use BGP over QUIC. Complementary to it, this document specifies a mechanism to support BGP multisessions using QUIC streams.

section.title: QUIC Multi-streams
section.t: QUIC is a UDP-based multiplexed and secure transport protocol. It provides connection-oriented and stateful interaction between a client and server. QUIC integrates TLS and allow the exchange of application data as soon as possible.

In QUIC, application protocols exchange information via streams, and multiple streams can be multiplexed onto an underlying connection. Each stream is a separate unidirectional or bidirectional channel of "order stream of bytes". Each stream has flow control which limits bytes sent on a stream.

section.title: Multiple BGP sessions over QUIC streams
section.t: This draft proposes to start BGP peering sessions based on AFI/SAFI. It's possible to set but sessions use different options , such as proposed in , but that's out of scope of this draft.
Connection Collision Detection procedure of the BGP specification needs to be modified to allow using AFI/SAFI to determine the session uniqueness. Each BGP session operates independently.

Before creating a new session, it should be checked that no session exists for the AFI/SAFI peers. If there is an existing session for the AFI/SAFI peers, a BGP speaker SHOULD NOT attempt to create a new session, and a local error may be logged.
If a BGP speaker receives an OPEN message and there is already an existing session for the same AFI/SAFI, it SHOULD ignore this OPEN message.

When a BGP speaker is running multisessions, and there is an error, such as malformed message, in one session that requires the session to be terminated or reset, it SHOULD only reset the session impacted, not any other sessions.

section.title: Use of Multiple OPEN Messages
section.t:
Each BGP session is established using its own OPEN message. New BGP capability code to indicate that a BGP speaker supports multi sessions is defined.
Capability code (1 octet): TBD Capability length (1 octet): variable Capability value (1 octet): flags followed by the AFI/SAFI of the session.
R - indicates this session is a restart.
Reserved - MUST be set to zero by sender, MUST be ignored by receiver.
AFI/SAFI - //****whether to have AFI/SAFI here or use MP-BGP capability
When BGP multisession is enabled, BGP speaker MUST advertise Multisession capability in OPEN message on every session.

When BGP over QUIC is used, multisession should be enabled by default, unless configured otherwise. BGP speaker MUST advertise Multisession Capability in then OPEN message on every session. When a multisession capable BGP speaker receives an OPEN message without Mutisession Capability, it MUST assume the peer is not multisession capable, and fall back to single session BGP.

section.title: Session Prioritization
section.t: One of the major drawbacks of a single session BGP is that packets from all AFI/SAFI are sent through this single session, and this may cause resource contention.

QUIC does not provide a mechanism or exchanging prioritization information. It relies on the application's receiving priority information. QUIC suggests an implementation SHOULD provide ways for an application to indicate the relative priority of streams. BGP sessions should be created using different priorities. AFI/SAFI that carries routing information should be given higher priority.

section.title: Other Considerations
section.t: A configuration command SHOULD be implemented to enable or disable multisession.
Implementations supporting multisession BGP SHOULD have show commands to view the state of each individual session, notifications and logs.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: This document does not change the BGP security model.
